awd_titl_txt: Water Sustainability in Snow-Fed Arid Land River System
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will create a framework to engage diverse stakeholder communities interacting with regard to water within the Truckee-Carson River System of northern Nevada.  The approach, combining a systems-based hydrologic model and an agent-based stakeholder model, has the potential to inform and transform water management in Northern Nevada and the American Southwest. This project will produce new models and actionable information for Tribal, Federal, State, and local resource managers and policy makers. Two federally recognized American Indian tribes (Pyramid Lake Paiute and Fallon Paiute-Shoshone) will be engaged to increase the capacity of the Indian Tribal Governments to effectively steward natural and water resources on reservation lands.  Presentations will also be made to the Intertribal Agriculture Council, the Board of the Indian Land Tenure Foundation (600-700 tribal members per meeting) and the Association for International Agriculture and Extension Education.  Engagement with Latino groups will occur through the student diversity office.  Three post-docs and two graduate students will be trained as well as two UG students who will participate in the summer research REU.  

This project will develop an integrated systems-based approach (1) to predict (a) the robustness of the Truckee-Carson River System (TCRS) water supply to future hydroclimatic conditions, (b) the resilience of the system to extreme events and changes in land-use and economic growth, and (2) to assess stakeholder acceptance of alternative water policy institutional arrangements designed to enhance sustainability.  A water supply model will be linked to both climate projections and extreme weather events, as well as an agent-based model to simulate the behavior of water rights holders and users along the system. Stakeholders will be engaged throughout the project to enhance understanding of how individuals and policy institutions might respond to future hydroclimatic conditions, assess the adaptive capacity of current water management agreements and, as adaptive capacity is reached, test the willingness of stakeholders to accept new policies and practices.

por.por_cntn:
Water for the Seasons, a NSF/USDA funded Water Sustainability & Climate project, developed an integrated system-wide approach to model climate resiliency in snow-fed arid land river systems. The Truckee-Carson River System (TCRS) in Northern Nevada served as the study area for understanding how best to link science with decision-making to improve the capacity of water managers and users to respond and adapt to changes in climate. The Water for the Seasons project was a multi-disciplinary, collaborative research project that engaged stakeholders from the headwaters to the terminus of the TCRS. Stakeholder partners included urban water authorities, agricultural irrigation districts, Tribal water and natural resource managers, federal and state water agencies responsible for water supplies and infrastructure (dams, canals, and aquifers), regional planning agencies, and environmental conservation groups. 

As a result of this collaborative approach, the Water for the Seasons project was able to build trust among diverse groups, encourage respectful dialogue about the impacts of climate on increasingly scarce water supplies, and reduce conflict when considering options to enhance water sustainability. Collaborative modeling methods (surveys, interviews, focus groups) created stakeholder-informed hydroclimatic models that were used to assess the impacts of climate on water management, system-wide. A Stakeholder Affiliate Group (SAG) comprised of leaders from twelve major groups representing interests from the headwaters (Lake Tahoe) to the terminus (Pyramid Lake and Stillwater Refuge) met biannually with researchers to consider options for enhancing water sustainability during extended droughts and increased precipitation variability. Economic modeling assessed the impact of Prior Appropriations Doctrine on water allocations and use. Results were shared extensively during biannual meetings of the Nevada Water Resources Association, research conferences, scientific publications, and through Cooperative Extension fact sheets, special reports, and training materials designed to support climate-informed stakeholder water management. 

Results from Water for the Seasons continue to be used to inform water sustainability and climate resiliency planning by stakeholders in the TCRS and have been shared with groups in other snow-fed arid land systems, nationally and internationally. Key findings include,

  • In the snow-fed TCRS, there was broad recognition among water managers and users of the need to adapt to a ?new normal? that includes increased hydroclimate variability, warmer temperatures, longer droughts, and more extreme floods. Managers and researchers proved willing to collaborate to assess the viability of locally identified alternative water management options in a nonstationary climate when a collaborative modeling approach was used.
  • A method developed for the co-development of climate scenarios with decision makers provided insight into how to incorporate climate modeling output planning and implementation actions for climate adaptation and resilience.   
  • Hydroclimatic modeling showed warming temperatures will result in more rain and less snow, reduced snowpack, and earlier snowmelt. These factors adversely impact irrigated agriculture in the arid lands of the Great Basin that depends entirely on snowmelt-derived surface water and limited groundwater resources. 
  • Options for capturing water for agriculture earlier in the water year are limited due to institutional arrangements around flood management operations, federal and state water allocation agreements, and risk of adverse impacts to critical ecosystems downstream of agricultural areas. 
  • Changes in the patterns of wet and dry years will have significant impacts on basin water supplies and operations, with the greatest impacts to agriculture stakeholders who do not have interannual water storage capabilities or capacity.
  • Negotiated legal operating agreements among federal, tribal, and state entities, allocated reservoir capacity, and the Endangered Species Act were essential to guaranteeing minimum flows in the Truckee River to protect Native fish populations. Without these instruments, Native communities would not have had standing to exercise their senior water rights under Prior Appropriations Law to protect traditionally important fish species.  
  • An empirical model, developed using data for agricultural irrigation water rights, shows that for transferred water rights, more senior (high-priority) rights are reallocated from lower-to higher-valued agricultural uses. For water rights that remained unchanged, the priority order and potential profitability, as indicated by land characteristics, are not well aligned.

A key finding of the Water for the Seasons project is that even in a tightly networked, geographically compact river system more flexible governance structures, and a reduction in institutional and economic barriers at the federal, state, and local levels, are needed to achieve robust, systems-wide water resilience. These are likely to include, although not be limited to:

  • Water banking/trading structures among agriculture water users and irrigation districts
  • Changes to flood management controls to increase water storage earlier in the water year
  • Managed aquifer recharge systems to conserve winter runoff as groundwater that can be pumped later for agricultural use
  • Increased conservation measures by urban water authorities that incentivize reduced consumption without causing economic losses to water management entities
  • Ecological and fish habitat restoration activities to protect critical species from rising water temperatures and reduced flows
